The '''Paris Agreement''' ({{lang-fr|Accord de Paris}}), often referred to as the '''Paris Accords''' or the '''Paris Climate Accords''', is an international treaty on [[climate change]]. Adopted in 2015, the agreement covers [[climate change mitigation]], [[Climate change adaptation|adaptation]], and [[Climate finance|finance]]. The Paris Agreement was negotiated by 196 [[party (law)|parties]] at the [[2015 United Nations Climate Change Conference]] near [[Paris, France]]. As of September 2022, 194 members of the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC) are parties to the agreement. Of the four UNFCCC member states which have not [[Ratification|ratified]] the agreement, the only major emitter is Iran. The United States withdrew from the Agreement in 2020, but rejoined in 2021.

The Paris Agreement was opened for signature on 22 April 2016 ([[Earth Day]]) at a ceremony in [[New York (state)|New York]]. After the [[European Union]] ratified the agreement, sufficient countries had ratified the Agreement responsible for enough of the [[greenhouse gas emissions|world's greenhouse gases]] for the Agreement to enter into force on 4 November 2016. 

The Paris Agreement's long-term temperature goal is to keep the rise in mean global temperature to well below {{convert|2|C-change}} above pre-industrial levels, and preferably limit the increase to {{convert|1.5|C-change}}, recognizing that this would substantially reduce the [[effects of climate change]]. Emissions should be reduced as soon as possible and reach [[net-zero emissions|net-zero]] by the middle of the 21st century.<ref>{{Cite web|last=UNFCCC|title=The Paris Agreement|url=https://unfccc.int/process-and-meetings/the-paris-agreement/the-paris-agreement|url-status=live|access-date=18 September 2021|website=unfccc.int|archive-date=19 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210319205057/https://unfccc.int/process-and-meetings/the-paris-agreement/the-paris-agreement}}</ref> To stay below 1.5{{Nbsp}}°C of global warming, emissions need to be cut by roughly 50% by 2030. This is an aggregate of each country's [[nationally determined contribution]]s.<ref name=":17">{{Cite web|last=Schleussner|first=Carl-Friedrich|title=The Paris Agreement – the 1.5 °C Temperature Goal|url=https://climateanalytics.org/briefings/15c/|access-date=2022-01-29|website=Climate Analytics|language=en}}</ref>

It aims to help countries adapt to climate change effects, and mobilise enough finance. Under the Agreement, each country must determine, plan, and [[Enhanced Transparency Framework|regularly report]] on its contributions. No mechanism forces a country to set specific [[emissions target]]s, but each target should go beyond previous targets. In contrast to the 1997 [[Kyoto Protocol]], the distinction between developed and developing countries is blurred, so that the latter also have to submit plans for emission reductions.

The Agreement was lauded by world leaders, but criticised as insufficiently binding by some environmentalists and analysts. There is debate about the effectiveness of the Agreement. While [[Nationally Determined Contributions|current pledges]] under the Paris Agreement are insufficient for reaching the set temperature goals, there is a mechanism of [[Global stocktake|increased ambition]]. The Paris Agreement has been successfully used in [[Climate change litigation|climate litigation]] forcing countries and an oil company to strengthen climate action. On 4 July 2022, the [[Supreme Federal Court]] of [[Brazil]] recognized the Paris agreement as a [[Human rights treaty bodies|human rights treaty]].<ref name="stf-jus-jul22">{{cite web|title=Arguição de descumprimento de preceito fundamental|language=pt|url=https://portal.stf.jus.br/processos/detalhe.asp?incidente=5951856|website=[[Supremo Tribunal Federal]]|access-date=24 July 2022|archive-date=24 July 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220724145637/https://portal.stf.jus.br/processos/detalhe.asp?incidente=5951856}}</ref><ref name="yale-bra-jul22">{{cite web |last1=Ciuffo |first1=Leandro Neumann |title=Brazil's High Court First to Declare Paris Agreement a Human Rights Treaty |url=https://e360.yale.edu/digest/paris-agreement-human-rights-treaty-brazil |website=Yale Program on Climate Change Communication |date=7 July 2022|access-date=21 July 2022|archive-date=24 July 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220724144613/https://e360.yale.edu/digest/paris-agreement-human-rights-treaty-brazil}}</ref>

===Lead-up===
The [[UN Framework Convention on Climate Change]] (UNFCCC), adopted at the 1992 [[Earth Summit]] is one of the first international treaties on the topic. It stipulates that parties should meet regularly to address climate change, at the [[Conference of Parties]] or COP. It forms the foundation to future climate agreements.<ref>{{cite web|title=UN Climate Talks|access-date=20 July 2021|website=Council of Foreign Affairs|url=https://www.cfr.org/timeline/un-climate-talks|year=2021|archive-date=20 July 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210720114238/https://www.cfr.org/timeline/un-climate-talks|url-status=live}}</ref>

The [[Kyoto Protocol]], adopted in 1997, regulated [[greenhouse gas]] reductions for a limited set of countries from 2008 to 2012. The protocol was extended until 2020 with the Doha Amendment in 2012.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Harrabin | first1=Roger |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20653018  |title= UN climate talks extend Kyoto Protocol, promise compensation  |work= BBC News  |date= 8 December 2012 |access-date= 22 June 2018 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20180716140524/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-20653018  |archive-date= 16 July 2018 |url-status= live  |df= dmy-all  }}</ref> The United States decided not to ratify the Protocol, mainly because of its legally-binding nature. This, and distributional conflict, led to failures of subsequent international climate negotiations. The 2009 negotiations were intended to produce a successor treaty of Kyoto, but the negotiations collapsed and the resulting [[Copenhagen Accord]] was not legally binding and did not get adopted universally.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Falkner|first=Robert|date=2016|title=The Paris Agreement and the new logic of international climate politics|url=https://academic.oup.com/ia/article/92/5/1107/2688148|journal=International Affairs|language=en|volume=92|issue=5|pages=1107–1125|doi=10.1111/1468-2346.12708|issn=0020-5850|access-date=7 March 2021|archive-date=3 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180603060439/https://academic.oup.com/ia/article/92/5/1107/2688148|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Klein|first=Richard J. T.|date=7 December 2020|title=The Paris Agreement and the future of climate negotiations|url=https://www.sei.org/perspectives/paris-agreement-and-future-of-climate-negotiations/|url-status=live|access-date=18 July 2021|website=Stockholm Environment Institute|language=en-GB|archive-date=18 July 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210718165725/https://www.sei.org/perspectives/paris-agreement-and-future-of-climate-negotiations/}}</ref>

The Accord did lay the framework for bottom-up approach of the Paris Agreement.<ref name=":11" /> Under the leadership of UNFCCC executive secretary [[Christiana Figueres]], negotiation regained momentum after Copenhagen's failure.<ref>{{Cite news|last=McGrath|first=Matt|date=19 February 2016|title=UN climate chief Christiana Figueres to step down|language=en-GB|work=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-35612559|url-status=live|access-date=7 March 2021|archive-date=29 December 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201229230045/https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-35612559}}</ref> During the [[2011 United Nations Climate Change Conference]], the [[Durban Platform for Enhanced Action|Durban Platform]] was established to negotiate a legal instrument governing [[climate change mitigation]] measures from 2020. The platform had a mandate to be informed by the Fifth Assessment Report of the IPCC and the work of the subsidiary bodies of the UNFCCC.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://doi.org/10.1163/18719732-bja10068 |title= The Nexus between International Law and Science: An Analysis of Scientific Expert Bodies in Multilateral Treaty-Making |newspaper=International Community Law Review |date=April 1, 2022  |author=Orangias, Joseph |doi= 10.1163/18719732-bja10068 |s2cid= 248057340 |access-date= May 6, 2022}}</ref> The resulting agreement was to be adopted in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unfccc.int/bodies/body/6645.php|title=UNFCCC:Ad Hoc Working Group on the Durban Platform for Enhanced Action (ADP)|access-date=2 August 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150802050511/http://unfccc.int/bodies/body/6645.php|archive-date=2 August 2015|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Negotiations and adoption ===

=== Signing and entry into force ===

Headquarters in New York.<ref>{{cite web|title=Article The Agreement would enter into force (and thus become fully effective) if 55 countries that produce at least 55% of [[List of countries by greenhouse gas emissions|the world's greenhouse gas emissions]] (according to a list produced in 2015)<ref name="ratpct">{{cite web|title=Information provided in accordance with paragraph 104 of decision 1 CP21 related to entry into force of the Paris Agreement (Article 21)|url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2015/cop21/eng/10.pdf#page=30|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160221204004/http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2015/cop21/eng/10.pdf#page=30|archive-date=21 February 2016|access-date=23 April 2016|work=UNFCCC}}</ref> ratify or otherwise join the treaty.<ref>Article 21(1)</ref><ref name=":13" /> Alternative ways to join the treaty are acceptance, approval or accession. The first two are typically used when a head of state is not necessary to bind a country to a treaty, whereas the latter typically happens when a country joins a treaty already in force.<ref>{{cite web |title=Glossary of terms relating to Treaty actions |url=https://treaties.un.org/Pages/Overview.aspx?path=overview/glossary/page1_en.xml#acceptance |website=United Nations Treaty Collection |language=EN |access-date=18 July 2021 |archive-date=22 May 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190522074345/https://treaties.un.org/Pages/Overview.aspx?path=overview%2Fglossary%2Fpage1_en.xml#acceptance |url-status=live }}</ref> After ratification by the European Union, the Agreement obtained enough parties to enter into effect on 4 November 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Yeo|first=Sophie|date=6 October 2016|title=Explainer: Paris Agreement on climate change to 'enter into force'|url=https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-paris-agreement-to-enter-into-force|access-date=8 May 2021|website=Carbon Brief|language=en|archive-date=8 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210508084316/https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-paris-agreement-to-enter-into-force|url-status=live}}</ref>

Both the EU and its member states are individually responsible for ratifying the Paris Agreement. A strong preference was reported that the EU and its 28 member states ratify at the same time to ensure that they do not engage themselves to fulfilling obligations that strictly belong to the other,<ref name="eurat">{{cite web|last=Yeo|first=Sophie|date=23 June 2016|title=Explainer: When will the European Union ratify the Paris Agreement?|url=https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-when-will-european-union-ratify-paris-agreement|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160905103935/http://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-when-will-european-union-ratify-paris-agreement|archive-date=5 September 2016|access-date=3 September 2016|website=Carbon Brief}}</ref> and there were fears by observers that disagreement over each member state's share of the EU-wide reduction target, as well as Britain's [[Brexit|vote to leave the EU]] might delay the Paris pact.<ref name = "Nature">{{cite journal|url=http://www.nature.com/news/paris-climate-deal-to-take-effect-as-eu-ratifies-accord-1.20735|title=Paris climate deal to take effect as EU ratifies accord|journal=Nature|date=4 October 2016|access-date=5 October 2016|doi=10.1038/nature.2016.20735|last1=Schiermeier|first1=Quirin|s2cid=158043198|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005125351/http://www.nature.com/news/paris-climate-deal-to-take-effect-as-eu-ratifies-accord-1.20735|archive-date=5 October 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> However, the EU deposited its instruments of ratification on 5 October 2016, along with seven EU member states.<ref name="Nature" />

==Content==
The Paris Agreement is a short agreement with 16 introductory paragraphs and 29 articles. It contains procedural (e.g. the criteria for entry into force) and operational articles (mitigation, [[Climate change adaptation|adaptation]] and finance). It is a binding agreement, but many of its articles do not imply obligations or are there to facilitate international collaboration.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Savaresi|first=Annalisa|date=2016|title=The Paris Agreement: a new beginning?|url=https://dspace.stir.ac.uk/bitstream/1893/24099/1/ParisAgreementANewBeginning.pdf|journal=Journal of Energy & Natural Resources Law|volume=34|issue=1|pages=16–26|doi=10.1080/02646811.2016.1133983|s2cid=146999274|issn=0264-6811|hdl=1893/24099|hdl-access=free|access-date=24 July 2021|archive-date=24 July 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210724140207/https://dspace.stir.ac.uk/bitstream/1893/24099/1/ParisAgreementANewBeginning.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> It covers most greenhouse gas emissions, but does not apply to international aviation and shipping, which fall under the responsibility of the [[International Civil Aviation Organization]] and the [[International Maritime Organization]], respectively.<ref>{{cite book

}}</ref>

===Aims===
The aim of the agreement, as described in Article 2, is to have a stronger response to the danger of climate change; it seeks to enhance the implementation of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change through:<ref name=":0">{{cite web|url = http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2015/cop21/eng/l09r01.pdf|work = UNFCCC secretariat|title = Paris Agreement, FCCC/CP/2015/L.9/Rev.1|access-date = 12 December 2015|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151212194411/http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2015/cop21/eng/l09r01.pdf|archive-date = 12 December 2015|url-status = live|df = dmy-all}}</ref>

{{blockquote|(a) Holding the increase in the global average temperature to well below 2 °C above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase to 1.5 °C above pre-industrial levels, recognizing that this would significantly reduce the risks and impacts of climate change;

(b) Increasing the ability to adapt to the adverse impacts of climate change and foster [[climate resilience]] and low greenhouse gas emissions development, in a manner that does not threaten food production;

(c) Making finance flows consistent with a pathway towards low greenhouse gas emissions and climate-resilient development.}}

Countries furthermore aim to reach "global peaking of greenhouse gas emissions as soon as possible."<ref name=":0" />

=== {{anchor|Nationally determined contributions and their limits}} Nationally determined contributions ===
[[File:Total CO2 by Region.svg|thumb|upright=1.35|Since 2000, rising {{CO2}} emissions in China and the rest of the world have surpassed the output of the United States and Europe.]]
[[File:Per Capita CO2 by Region.svg|thumb|upright=1.35|Per person, the United States generates {{CO2}} at a far faster rate than other primary regions.]]
Countries determine themselves what contributions they should make to achieve the aims of the treaty. As such, these plans are called ''[[nationally determined contributions]]'' (NDCs).<ref name=Article3>Article 3, Paris Agreement (2015)</ref> Article 3 requires NDCs to be "ambitious efforts" towards "achieving the purpose of this Agreement" and to "represent a progression over time".<ref name=Article3 /> The contributions should be set every five years and are to be registered by the [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change#Secretariat|UNFCCC Secretariat]].<ref>Article 4(9), Paris Agreement (2015)</ref> Each further ambition should be more ambitious than the previous one, known as the principle of 'progression'.<ref>Articles 3, 9(3), Paris Agreement (2015)</ref> Countries can cooperate and pool their nationally determined contributions. The Intended Nationally Determined Contributions pledged during the [[2015 Climate Change Conference]] are converted to NDCs when a country ratifies the Paris Agreement, unless they submit an update.<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Taibi|first1=Fatima-Zahra|url=https://ecbi.org/sites/default/files/2020%20Pocket%20Guide%20to%20NDCs.pdf|title=Pocket Guide to NDCs : 2020 Edition|last2=Konrad|first2=Susanne|last3=Bois von Kursk|first3=Olivier|publisher=European Capacity Building Initiative|year=2020|editor-last=Sharma|editor-first=Anju|page=1|access-date=15 May 2021|archive-date=17 April 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210417170754/https://ecbi.org/sites/default/files/2020%20Pocket%20Guide%20to%20NDCs.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|last=Staff|date=22 November 2019|title=National Climate Action under the Paris Agreement|url=https://www.wri.org/ndcs|access-date=13 May 2021|website=World Resources Institute|language=en|archive-date=13 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210513062710/https://www.wri.org/ndcs|url-status=live}}</ref>

The Paris Agreement does not prescribe the exact nature of the NDCs. At a minimum, they should contain mitigation provisions, but they may also contain pledges on adaptation, finance, [[technology transfer]], [[capacity building]] and transparency.<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Taibi|first1=Fatima-Zahra|url=https://ecbi.org/sites/default/files/2020%20Pocket%20Guide%20to%20NDCs.pdf|title=Pocket Guide to NDCs : 2020 Edition|last2=Konrad|first2=Susanne|last3=Bois von Kursk|first3=Olivier|publisher=European Capacity Building Initiative|year=2020|editor-last=Sharma|editor-first=Anju|page=17|access-date=15 May 2021|archive-date=17 April 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210417170754/https://ecbi.org/sites/default/files/2020%20Pocket%20Guide%20to%20NDCs.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> Some of the pledges in the NDCs are unconditional, but others are conditional on outside factors such as getting finance and technical support, the  ambition from other parties or the details of rules of the Paris Agreement that are yet to be set. Most NDCs have a conditional component.<ref>{{Cite book|last1=Taibi|first1=Fatima-Zahra|url=https://ecbi.org/sites/default/files/2020%20Pocket%20Guide%20to%20NDCs.pdf|title=Pocket Guide to NDCs : 2020 Edition|last2=Konrad|first2=Susanne|last3=Bois von Kursk|first3=Olivier|publisher=European Capacity Building Initiative|year=2020|editor-last=Sharma|editor-first=Anju|pages=32–33|access-date=15 May 2021|archive-date=17 April 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210417170754/https://ecbi.org/sites/default/files/2020%20Pocket%20Guide%20to%20NDCs.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Global stocktake ===
Under the Paris Agreement, countries must increase their ambition every five years. To facilitate this, the Agreement established the [[Global stocktake|Global Stocktake]], which assesses progress, with the first evaluation in 2023. The outcome is to be used as input for new nationally determined contributions of parties.<ref>article 14 {{cite web|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=12 December 2015|title=Framework Convention on Climate Change|url=http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2015/cop21/eng/l09.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151212201810/http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/2015/cop21/eng/l09.pdf|archive-date=12 December 2015|access-date=12 December 2015|website=United Nations FCCC Int.|publisher=United Nations}}</ref> The [[Talanoa Dialogue]] in 2018 was seen as an example for the global stocktake.<ref>{{Cite report|url=https://newclimate.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/iGST-NewClimate-Questions-for-the-Global-Stocktake-1.pdf|title=Guiding questions for the Global Stocktake under the Paris Agreement|last1=Höhne|first1=Niklas|last2=Louise|first2=Jeffery|date=November 2019|publisher=NewClimate Institute|last3=Nilsson|first3=Anna|last4=Fekete|first4=Hanna|access-date=7 March 2021|archive-date=10 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210310232917/https://newclimate.org/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/iGST-NewClimate-Questions-for-the-Global-Stocktake-1.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> After a year of discussion, a report was published and there was a call for action, but countries did not increase ambition afterwards.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Hermwille|first1=Lukas|last2=Siemons|first2=Anne|last3=Förster|first3=Hannah|last4=Jeffery|first4=Louise|date=2019|title=Catalyzing mitigation ambition under the Paris Agreement: elements for an effective Global Stocktake|journal=Climate Policy|volume=19|issue=8|pages=988–1001|doi=10.1080/14693062.2019.1624494|s2cid=197773078|issn=1469-3062|doi-access=free}}</ref>

The stocktake works as part of the Paris Agreement's effort to create a "ratcheting up" of ambition in emissions cuts. Because analysts agreed in 2014 that the NDCs would not limit rising temperatures below 2 °C, the global stocktake reconvenes parties to assess how their new NDCs must evolve so that they continually reflect a country's "highest possible ambition".<ref name=":1">{{cite web|last=Yeo|first=Sophie|date=19 January 2016|title=The Paris Agreement "Ratchet Mechanism"|url=https://www.carbonbrief.org/timeline-the-paris-agreements-ratchet-mechanism|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119055158/https://www.carbonbrief.org/timeline-the-paris-agreements-ratchet-mechanism|archive-date=19 November 2016|website=Carbon Brief}}</ref> While ratcheting up the ambition of NDCs is a major aim of the global stocktake, it assesses efforts beyond mitigation. The 5-year reviews will also evaluate adaptation, [[climate finance]] provisions, and technology development and transfer.<ref name=":1" />

=== Structure ===
The Paris Agreement has been described as having a bottom-up structure, as its core [[pledge and review]] mechanism allows nations to set their own NDCs, rather than having targets imposed top down.<ref name ="Falkner">{{cite journal
|author= Robert Falkner
|title= The Paris Agreement and the new logic of international climate politics
|journal= [[International Affairs (journal)|International Affairs]]
|volume= 92
|year= 2016
|issue= 5
|pages= 1107–1125
|doi= 10.1111/1468-2346.12708
|url= http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/67741/2/Falkner_Paris%20agreement_2016.pdf
|access-date= 15 July 2021
|archive-date= 30 October 2021
|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20211030043759/http://eprints.lse.ac.uk/67741/2/Falkner_Paris%20agreement_2016.pdf
|url-status= live
}}</ref><ref>{{cite book
 |authors=[[Andrew Dessler]], Edward A Parson
 | title =The Science and Politics of Global Climate Change: A Guide to the Debate
 | year = 2020
 | isbn = 978-1-316-63132-4
 | publisher=[[Cambridge University Press]]
 | pages = 28, 137–148, 175–179
}}</ref> Unlike its predecessor, the Kyoto Protocol, which sets commitment targets that have legal force, the Paris Agreement, with its emphasis on [[Consensus decision-making|consensus building]], allows for voluntary and nationally determined targets.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|url=https://cdn.americanprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/15030725/ParisClimateAgreement.pdf|title=The Paris Climate Agreement|last=Taraska|first=Gwynne|date=15 December 2015|publisher=Center for American Progress|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161118224648/https://cdn.americanprogress.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/15030725/ParisClimateAgreement.pdf|archive-date=18 November 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> The specific climate goals are thus politically encouraged, rather than legally bound. Only the processes governing the reporting and review of these goals are mandated under [[international law]]. This structure is especially notable for the United States—because there are no legal mitigation or finance targets, the Agreement is considered an "executive agreement rather than a treaty". Because the UNFCCC treaty of 1992 received the consent of the US Senate, this new agreement does not require further legislation.<ref name=":2" />

Another key difference between the Paris Agreement and the Kyoto Protocol is their scope. The Kyoto Protocol differentiated between [[List of parties to the Kyoto Protocol|Annex-I]], richer countries with a historical responsibility for climate change, and non-Annex-I countries, but this division is blurred in the Paris Agreement as all parties are required to submit emissions reduction plans.<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/paris-climate-talks-differentiation-of-developed-and-developing-stays-india-happy/|title=Paris climate talks: Differentiation of developed and developing stays, India happy|last=Sinha|first=Amitabh|date=14 December 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160920110254/http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-news-india/paris-climate-talks-differentiation-of-developed-and-developing-stays-india-happy/|archive-date=20 September 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> The Paris Agreement still emphasises the principle of [[Common But Differentiated Responsibilities|Common but Differentiated Responsibility and Respective Capabilities]]—the acknowledgement that different nations have different capacities and duties to climate action—but it does not provide a specific division between developed and developing nations.<ref name=":3" />

== Mitigation provisions and carbon markets ==
Article 6 has been flagged as containing some of the key provisions of the Paris Agreement.<ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=http://www.ieta.org/resources/Resources/Position_Papers/2016/IETA_Article_6_Implementation_Paper_May2016.pdf|title=Article 6 Implementation Paper|date=20 May 2016|website=International Emissions Trading Association|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161017115236/http://ieta.org/resources/Resources/Position_Papers/2016/IETA_Article_6_Implementation_Paper_May2016.pdf|archive-date=17 October 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Broadly, it outlines the [[Cooperative Mechanisms under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement|cooperative approaches]] that parties can take in achieving their nationally determined carbon emissions reductions. In doing so, it helps establish the Paris Agreement as a framework for a global carbon market.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Stavins|first=Robert|year=2016|title=Market Mechanisms in the Paris Climate Agreement: International Linkage under Article 6.2|url=http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/files/2016-10_paris-agreement-beyond_v4.pdf#page=59|url-status=dead|journal=Harvard Project on Climate Agreements|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119062203/http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/files/2016-10_paris-agreement-beyond_v4.pdf#page=59|archive-date=19 November 2016|access-date=18 November 2016}}</ref> Article 6 is the only important part of the Agreement yet to be resolved; [[2019 United Nations Climate Change Conference|negotiations in 2019]] did not produce a result.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Simon|last2=Gabbatiss|first2=John|date=29 November 2019|title=In-depth Q&A: How 'Article 6' carbon markets could 'make or break' the Paris Agreement|url=https://www.carbonbrief.org/in-depth-q-and-a-how-article-6-carbon-markets-could-make-or-break-the-paris-agreement|url-status=live|access-date=7 March 2021|website=Carbon Brief|language=en|archive-date=20 April 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200420143355/https://www.carbonbrief.org/in-depth-q-and-a-how-article-6-carbon-markets-could-make-or-break-the-paris-agreement}}</ref> The topic is now expected to be settled during the [[2021 United Nations Climate Change Conference|2021 negotiations in Glasgow]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Kosolapova|first=Elena|date=24 March 2021|title=Policy Brief: Delivering Climate Ambition Through Market Mechanisms: Capitalizing on Article 6 Piloting Activities|url=https://sdg.iisd.org:443/commentary/policy-briefs/delivering-climate-ambition-through-market-mechanisms-capitalizing-on-article-6-piloting-activities/|access-date=4 April 2021|website=SDG Knowledge Hub {{!}} IISD|language=en-US|archive-date=26 March 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210326141044/https://sdg.iisd.org/commentary/policy-briefs/delivering-climate-ambition-through-market-mechanisms-capitalizing-on-article-6-piloting-activities/|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Linkage of carbon trading systems and ITMOs ===
[[Cooperative Mechanisms under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement#Article 6.2: Cooperative Approaches|Paragraphs 6.2]] and 6.3 establish a framework to govern the [[Internationally transferred mitigation outcomes|international transfer of mitigation outcomes]] (ITMOs). The Agreement recognises the rights of parties to use emissions reductions outside of their own borders toward their NDC, in a system of carbon accounting and trading.<ref name=":5" /> This provision requires the "linkage" of carbon emissions trading systems—because measured emissions reductions must avoid "double counting", transferred mitigation outcomes must be recorded as a gain of emission units for one party and a reduction of emission units for the other,<ref name=":4" /> a so called "corresponding adjustment".<ref>[https://unfccc.int/sites/default/files/resource/Art._6.2%2520_draft_decision.pdf UNFCCC.int - Draft CMA decision on guidance on cooperative approaches referred to in Art. 6, paragraph 2, of the Paris Agreement]</ref> Because the NDCs, and domestic carbon trading schemes, are heterogeneous, the ITMOs will provide a format for global linkage under the auspices of the UNFCCC.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|last=Marcu|first=Andrei|year=2016|editor-last=Stavins|editor-first=Robert|title=The Paris agreement and beyond|url=http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/files/2016-10_paris-agreement-beyond_v4.pdf#page=59|url-status=dead|publisher=Harvard Project on Climate Agreements|chapter=Governance of Carbon Markets under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119062203/http://belfercenter.ksg.harvard.edu/files/2016-10_paris-agreement-beyond_v4.pdf#page=59|archive-date=19 November 2016|access-date=18 November 2016}}</ref> The provision thus also creates a pressure for countries to adopt emissions management systems—if a country wants to use more cost-effective cooperative approaches to achieve their NDCs, they will have to monitor carbon units for their economies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theenergycollective.com/davidhone/2378184/a-vision-for-article-6-of-the-paris-agreement|title=A Vision for Article 6 of the Paris Agreement|last=Hone|first=David|date=16 May 2016|website=The Energy Collective|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161120003330/http://www.theenergycollective.com/davidhone/2378184/a-vision-for-article-6-of-the-paris-agreement|archive-date=20 November 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>

So far, as the only country who wants to buy ITMOs, Switzerland has signed deals regarding ITMO tradings with Peru, Ghana, Senegal, Georgia, Dominica, Vanuatu, Thailand and Ukraine.

=== Sustainable Development Mechanism ===
[[Cooperative Mechanisms under Article 6 of the Paris Agreement#Article 6.4: Mechanism to promote climate action and support sustainable development|Paragraphs 6.4]]-6.7 establish a mechanism "to contribute to the mitigation of greenhouse gases and support sustainable development".<ref>United Nations/ Framework Convention on Climate Change (2015) Adoption of the Paris Agreement, 21st Conference of the Parties, Paris: United Nations</ref> Though there is no official name for the mechanism as yet, it has been referred to as the Sustainable Development Mechanism or SDM.<ref>''"The Carbon Markets of Tomorrow: Taking Shape Today". Ecosystem Market Place. Retrieved 24 October 2016''</ref><ref name=":12" /> The SDM is considered to be the successor to the [[Clean Development Mechanism]], a mechanism under the Kyoto Protocol by which parties could collaboratively pursue emissions reductions.<ref>{{Cite book|publisher=Carbon Market Watch|last1=Kachi|first1=Aki|last2=Voigt|first2=Juliane|date=May 2017|title=Building blocks for a robust Sustainable Development Mechanism|url=https://carbonmarketwatch.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/BUILDING-BLOCKS-FOR-A-ROBUST-SUSTAINABLE-DEVELOPMENT-MECHANISM_WEB-SINGLE_FINAL.pdf|access-date=4 April 2021|page=2|archive-date=25 April 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210425061559/https://carbonmarketwatch.org/wp/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/BUILDING-BLOCKS-FOR-A-ROBUST-SUSTAINABLE-DEVELOPMENT-MECHANISM_WEB-SINGLE_FINAL.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>

The SDM is set to largely resemble the Clean Development Mechanism, with the dual goal of contributing to global GHG emissions reductions and supporting sustainable development.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.ceps.eu/download/publication/?id=9274&pdf=SR%20No%20128%20ACM%20Post%20COP21%20Analysis%20of%20Article%206.pdf|title=Carbon Market Provisions in the Paris Agreement (Article 6)|last=Marcu|first=Andrei|date=January 2016|publisher=Centre for Europe and Policy Studies|access-date=15 July 2021|isbn=978-94-6138-501-7|page=13|archive-date=2 July 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210702140041/https://www.ceps.eu/download/publication/?id=9274&pdf=SR%20No%20128%20ACM%20Post%20COP21%20Analysis%20of%20Article%206.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref> Though the structure and processes governing the SDM are not yet determined, certain similarities and differences from the Clean Development Mechanisms have become clear. A key difference is that the SDM will be available to all parties as opposed to only [[Annex I|Annex-I parties]], making it much wider in scope.<ref>"Recommendations for Article 6 of the Paris Agreement." Carbon Market Watch. Carbon Market Watch, 19 May 2016. Web. 10 October 2016.</ref>

The Clean Development Mechanism of the Kyoto Protocol was criticised for failing to produce either meaningful emissions reductions or sustainable development benefits in most instances.<ref>Böhm, Steffen. ''Upsetting the offset: the political economy of carbon markets''. London: MayFlyBooks, 2009,</ref> and for its complexity. It is possible that the SDM will see difficulties.<ref name=":6" />

== Climate change adaptation provisions ==
[[Climate change adaptation]] received more focus in Paris negotiations than in previous climate treaties. Collective, long-term adaptation goals are included in the Agreement, and countries must report on their adaptation actions, making it a parallel component with mitigation.<ref name=":7">{{cite journal|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/2015/12/what-does-paris-agreement-mean-climate-resilience-and-adaptation|title=What Does the Paris Agreement Mean for Climate Resilience and Adaptation|last=Mogelgaard|first=Kathleen|date=23 December 2015|website=World Resources Institute|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119060408/http://www.wri.org/blog/2015/12/what-does-paris-agreement-mean-climate-resilience-and-adaptation|archive-date=19 November 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> The adaptation goals focus on enhancing [[adaptive capacity]], increasing [[Climate resilience|resilience]], and limiting vulnerability.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/2015/12/paris-agreement-turning-point-climate-solution|title=The Paris Agreement: Turning Point for a Climate Solution|last=Morgan|first=Jennifer|date=12 December 2015|website=World Resources Institute|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119055526/http://www.wri.org/blog/2015/12/paris-agreement-turning-point-climate-solution|archive-date=19 November 2016|url-status=live}}</ref>

=== Ensuring finance ===
{{see also|Green Climate Fund}}
[[File:GCF Signed Pledges 2018.svg|thumb|alt=Map showing that the US, various European countries and Japan contributed most the Green Climate Fund|Pledges to the Green Climate Fund in 2018. The numbers represent the signed pledges per year.|upright=1.4]]
Developed countries reaffirmed the commitment to mobilise $100 billion a year in climate finance by 2020, and agreed to continue mobilising finance at this level until 2025.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/2015/12/what-does-paris-agreement-do-finance|title=What Does the Paris Agreement do for Finance?|last=Thwaites|first=Joe|date=18 December 2015|publisher=WRI|access-date=10 April 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170410215553/http://www.wri.org/blog/2015/12/what-does-paris-agreement-do-finance|archive-date=10 April 2017|url-status=live}}</ref> The money is for supporting mitigation and adaptation in developing countries.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.-->|date=13 December 2015|title=COP21 climate change summit reaches deal in Paris|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-35084374|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151213160112/http://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-35084374|archive-date=13 December 2015|access-date=14 December 2015|website=BBC News}}</ref> It includes finance for the [[Green Climate Fund]], which is a part of the UNFCCC, but also for a variety of other public and private pledges. The Paris Agreement states that a new commitment of at least $100 billion per year has to be agreed before 2025.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=J. Timmons|last2=Weikmans|first2=Romain|last3=Robinson|first3=Stacy-ann|last4=Ciplet|first4=David|last5=Khan|first5=Mizan|last6=Falzon|first6=Danielle|date=March 2021|title=Rebooting a failed promise of climate finance|journal=Nature Climate Change|language=en|volume=11|issue=3|pages=180–182|doi=10.1038/s41558-021-00990-2|bibcode=2021NatCC..11..180R|issn=1758-6798|doi-access=free}}</ref>

Though both mitigation and adaptation require increased climate financing, adaptation has typically received lower levels of support and has mobilized less action from the private sector.<ref name=":7" /> A report by the OECD found that 16% of global climate finance was directed toward climate adaptation in 2013–2014, compared to 77% for mitigation.<ref>{{Cite web|last=OECD|date=2015|title=Climate Finance in 2013–14 and the USD 100 billion goal|url=http://www.oecd.org/env/cc/Climate-Finance-in-2013-14-and-the-USD-billion-goal.pdf|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160530220000/http://www.oecd.org/env/cc/Climate-Finance-in-2013-14-and-the-USD-billion-goal.pdf|archive-date=30 May 2016|access-date=10 April 2017|page=20}}</ref> The Paris Agreement called for a balance of climate finance between adaptation and mitigation, and specifically increasing adaptation support for parties most vulnerable to the effects of climate change, including [[Least developed countries]] and [[Small Island Developing States]]. The Agreement also reminds parties of the importance of public grants, because adaptation measures receive less investment from the public sector.<ref name=":7" />

In 2015, twenty Multilateral Development Banks (MDBs) and members of the International Development Finance Club introduced five principles to maintain widespread climate action in their investments: commitment to climate strategies, managing climate risks, promoting climate smart objectives, improving climate performance and accounting for their own actions. As of January 2020, the number of members abiding by these principles grew to 44.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Climate Change 2022: Mitigation of Climate Change |url=https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg3/ |access-date=2022-04-06 |website=www.ipcc.ch |language=en}}</ref>

Some specific outcomes of the elevated attention to adaptation financing in Paris include the [[G7 countries]]' announcement to provide US$420 million for [[climate risk insurance]], and the launching of a Climate Risk and Early Warning Systems (CREWS) Initiative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dfat.gov.au/international-relations/themes/climate-change/Documents/climate-finance-roadmap-to-us100-billion.pdf|title=Roadmap to US$100 Billion|publisher=OECD|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119120116/http://dfat.gov.au/international-relations/themes/climate-change/Documents/climate-finance-roadmap-to-us100-billion.pdf|archive-date=19 November 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> The largest donors to multilateral climate funds, which includes the Green Climate Fund, are the United States, the United Kingdom, Japan, Germany, France and Sweden.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=Timperley|first1=Jocelyn|last2=Pearce|first2=Rosamund|date=6 November 2017|title=Mapped: Where multilateral climate funds spend their money|url=https://www.carbonbrief.org/mapped-where-multilateral-climate-funds-spend-their-money|access-date=8 May 2021|website=Carbon Brief|language=en|archive-date=7 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210507154928/https://www.carbonbrief.org/mapped-where-multilateral-climate-funds-spend-their-money|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Loss and damage ==
It is not possible to adapt to all effects of climate change: even in the case of optimal adaptation, severe damage may still occur. The Paris Agreement recognises [[loss and damage]] of this kind.<ref name="WorldResourcesInstitute">{{cite web|url=http://www.wri.org/blog/2015/12/when-adaptation-not-enough-paris-agreement-recognizes-%E2%80%9Closs-and-damage%E2%80%9D|title=When Adaptation is Not Enough|last=Mogelgaard|first=Kathleen|date=24 December 2015|website=World Resources Institute|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161008083845/http://www.wri.org/blog/2015/12/when-adaptation-not-enough-paris-agreement-recognizes-%E2%80%9Closs-and-damage%E2%80%9D|archive-date=8 October 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Loss and damage can stem from [[Extreme weather|extreme weather events]], or from slow-onset events such as the loss of land to [[sea level rise]] for low-lying islands.<ref name=":2" /> Previous climate agreements classified loss and damage as a subset of adaptation.<ref name="WorldResourcesInstitute" />

The push to address loss and damage as a distinct issue in the Paris Agreement came from the [[Alliance of Small Island States]] and the Least Developed Countries, whose economies and livelihoods are most vulnerable to the negative effects of climate change.<ref name=":2" /> The [[Warsaw Mechanism]], established two years earlier during COP19 and set to expire in 2016, categorises loss and damage as a subset of adaptation, which was unpopular with many countries. It is recognized as a separate pillar of the Paris Agreement.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Pidcock|first=Roz|date=9 May 2017|title=Explainer: Dealing with the 'loss and damage' caused by climate change|url=https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-dealing-with-the-loss-and-damage-caused-by-climate-change|access-date=8 May 2021|website=Carbon Brief|language=en|archive-date=8 May 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210508140245/https://www.carbonbrief.org/explainer-dealing-with-the-loss-and-damage-caused-by-climate-change|url-status=live}}</ref> The United States argued against this, possibly worried that classifying the issue as separate from adaptation would create yet another climate finance provision.<ref name=":2" /> In the end, the Agreement calls for "averting, minimizing, and addressing loss and damage"<ref name=":0" /> but specifies that it cannot be used as the basis for liability. The Agreement adopts the Warsaw Mechanism, an institution that will attempt to address questions about how to classify, address, and share responsibility for loss.<ref name="WorldResourcesInstitute" />

== Transparency ==
{{Main|Enhanced Transparency Framework}}
The parties are legally bound to have their progress tracked by technical expert review to assess achievement toward the NDC and to determine ways to strengthen ambition.<ref name=":9">{{cite web|url=http://www.climatefocus.com/sites/default/files/20151228%20COP%2021%20briefing%20FIN.pdf|title=The Paris Agreement Summary|date=28 December 2015|website=Climate Focus|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160509090559/http://www.climatefocus.com/sites/default/files/20151228%20COP%2021%20briefing%20FIN.pdf|archive-date=9 May 2016|url-status=live}}</ref> Article 13 of the Paris Agreement articulates an "enhanced transparency framework for action and support" that establishes harmonized [[Monitoring, reporting and verification|monitoring, reporting, and verification]] (MRV) requirements. Both developed and developing nations must report every two years on their mitigation efforts, and all parties will be subject to technical and peer review.<ref name=":9" />

While the enhanced transparency framework is universal, the framework is meant to provide "built-in flexibility" to distinguish between developed and developing countries' capacities. The Paris Agreement has provisions for an enhanced framework for capacity building, recognises the varying circumstances of countries, and notes that the technical expert review for each country consider that country's specific capacity for reporting.<ref name=":10">{{cite web|last=Van Asselt|first=Harro|date=2016|title=Putting the 'enhanced transparency framework' into action: Priorities for a key pillar of the Paris Agreement|url=https://mediamanager.sei.org/documents/Publications/Climate/SEI-PB-2016-Transparency-under-Paris-Agreement.pdf|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161119062033/https://www.sei-international.org/mediamanager/documents/Publications/Climate/SEI-PB-2016-Transparency-under-Paris-Agreement.pdf|archive-date=19 November 2016|website=Stockholm Environment Institute}}</ref> Parties to the Agreement send their first Biennial Transparency Report (BTR), and [[greenhouse gas inventory]] figures to the UNFCCC by 2024 and every two years after that. Developed countries submit their first BTR in 2022 and inventories annually from that year.<ref>{{Cite web|last=|first=|date=|title=Reporting and Review under the Paris Agreement|url=https://unfccc.int/process-and-meetings/transparency-and-reporting/reporting-and-review-under-the-paris-agreement|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201101022313/https://unfccc.int/process-and-meetings/transparency-and-reporting/reporting-and-review-under-the-paris-agreement|archive-date=1 November 2020|access-date=20 April 2020|website=unfccc.int}}</ref> The Agreement also develops a Capacity-Building Initiative for Transparency to assist developing countries in building the necessary [[institution]]s and processes for compliance.<ref name=":10" />

Flexibility can be incorporated into the enhanced transparency framework via the scope, level of detail, or frequency of reporting, tiered based on a country's capacity. The requirement for in-country technical reviews could be lifted for some less developed or small island developing countries. Ways to assess capacity include financial and human resources in a country necessary for NDC review.<ref name=":10" />

==Implementation and effectiveness==
The Paris Agreement is implemented via national policy. It would involve improvements to [[Energy conservation|energy efficiency]] to decrease the [[energy intensity]] of the global economy. Implementation also requires fossil fuel burning to be cut back and the share of [[sustainable energy]] to grow rapidly. Emissions are being reduced rapidly in the electricity sector, but not in the building, transport and heating sector. Some industries are difficult to decarbonise, and for those [[carbon dioxide removal]] may be necessary to achieve [[Carbon neutrality|net-zero emissions]].<ref name=":14" /> In a report released in 2022 the IPCC promotes the need for innovation and technological changes in combination with consumption and production behavioral changes to meet Paris Agreement objectives.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Frequently Asked Questions |url=https://www.ipcc.ch/report/ar6/wg3/about/frequently-asked-questions/ |access-date=2022-04-04 |website=www.ipcc.ch |language=en}}</ref>

To stay below 1.5{{Nbsp}}°C of global warming, emissions need to be cut by roughly 50% by 2030. This is an aggregate of each country's [[nationally determined contribution]]s. By mid-century, {{CO2}} emissions would need to be cut to zero, and total greenhouse gases would net to be net-zero just after mid-century.<ref name=":17"/>

There are barriers to implementing the Agreement. Some countries struggle to attract the finance necessary for investments in decarbonisation. Climate finance is fragmented, further complicating investments. Another issue is the lack of capabilities in government and other institutions to implement policy. [[Clean technology]] and [[knowledge transfer|knowledge]] is often not transferred to countries or places that need it.<ref name=":14">{{Cite === Effectiveness of mitigation ===

The effectiveness of the Paris Agreement to reach its climate goals is under debate, with most experts saying it is insufficient for its more ambitious goal of keeping global temperature rise under 1.5 °C.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last1=Raiser|first1=Kilian|last2=Kornek|first2=Ulrike|last3=Flachsland|first3=Christian|last4=Lamb|first4=William F|date=19 August 2020|title=Is the Paris Agreement effective? ==Litigation==
{{main|Climate change litigation}}
The Paris Agreement has become a focal point of climate change litigation. One of the first major cases in this area was ''[[State of the Netherlands v. Urgenda Foundation]]'', which was raised against the Netherlands' government after it had reduced its planned emissions reductions goal for 2030 prior to the Paris Agreement. After an initial ruling against the government in 2015 that required it to maintain its planned reduction, the decision was upheld on appeals through the [[Supreme Court of the Netherlands]] in 2019, ruling that the Dutch government failed to uphold human rights under Dutch law and the [[European Convention on Human Rights]] by lowering its emission targets.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Corder|first=Mike|date=20 December 2019|title=Activists cheer victory in landmark Dutch climate case|url=https://apnews.com/article/europe-the-hague-courts-supreme-courts-international-news-5534fe18ac5352ba43c74c9a64d6a20a|access-date=2 July 2021|website=AP news|language=en|archive-date=9 July 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210709190944/https://apnews.com/article/europe-the-hague-courts-supreme-courts-international-news-5534fe18ac5352ba43c74c9a64d6a20a|url-status=live}}</ref> The 2{{nbsp}}°C temperature target of the Paris Agreement provided part of the judgement's legal basis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Backes|first1=C. W. (Chris)|last2=Veen|first2=G. A. (Gerrit) van der|date=2020|title=Urgenda: the Final Judgment of the Dutch Supreme Court|url=https://brill.com/view/journals/jeep/17/3/article-p307_307.xml|journal=Journal for European Environmental & Planning Law|language=en|volume=17|issue=3|pages=307–321|doi=10.1163/18760104-01703004|issn=1876-0104|doi-access=free|access-date=2 July 2021|archive-date=18 August 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210818085638/https://brill.com/view/journals/jeep/17/3/article-p307_307.xml|url-status=live}}</ref> The Agreement, whose goals are enshrined in German law, also formed part of the argumentation in ''[[Neubauer et al. v. Germany]],'' where the court ordered Germany to reconsider its climate targets.<ref>{{Cite report|url=https://www.lse.ac.uk/granthaminstitute/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/Global-trends-in-climate-change-litigation_2021-snapshot.pdf|title=Global trends in climate change litigation : 2021 snapshot|last1=Setzer|first1=Joana|last2=Higham|first2=Catherine|date=July 2021|publisher=Grantham Research Institute on Climate Change and the Environment and Centre for Climate Change, Economics and Policy, London School of Economics and Political Science|page=24|access-date=24 July 2021|archive-date=7 July 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210707141424/https://www.lse.ac.uk/granthaminstitute/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/Global-trends-in-climate-change-litigation_2021-snapshot.pdf|url-status=live}}</ref>

In May 2021, the district court of [[The Hague]] ruled against oil company [[Royal Dutch Shell]] in ''[[Milieudefensie et al v Royal Dutch Shell]]''. The court ruled that it must cut its global emissions by 45% from 2019 levels by 2030, as it was in violation of human rights. This lawsuit was considered the first major application of the Paris Agreement towards a corporation.<ref>{{cite web | title = Court orders Royal Dutch Shell to cut carbon emissions by 45% by 2030 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/business/2021/may/26/court-orders-royal-dutch-shell-to-cut-carbon-emissions-by-45-by-2030 | first = Daniel | last = Boffey | work = [[The Guardian]] | date = 26 May 2021 | access-date = 26 May 2021 | archive-date = 26 May 2021 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210526142843/https://www.theguardian.com/business/2021/may/26/court-orders-royal-dutch-shell-to-cut-carbon-emissions-by-45-by-2030 | url-status = live }}</ref>

=== Paris agreement as a human rights issue ===
{{Further|Human rights}}
On 4 July 2022, the [[Supreme Federal Court]] of [[Brazil]] recognized the Paris agreement as a "[[Human rights treaty bodies|humans right treaty]]". According to the ruling of the court in Brazil it should "supersede national law".<ref name="stf-jus-jul22" /><ref name="yale-bra-jul22" /> In the same month the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] in a resolution "(A/HRC/50/L.10/Rev.1) on Human rights and climate change, adopted without a vote" called to ratify and implement the agreement and emphasised the link between stopping climate change and the right to food.<ref>{{cite web |title=Human Rights Council Adopts Nine Resolutions – Extends Mandates on Eritrea, Internally Displaced Persons, and Violence Against Women and Girls |url=https://www.ohchr.org/en/press-releases/2022/07/human-rights-council-adopts-nine-resolutions-extends-mandates-eritrea |website=The Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights |publisher=United Nations |access-date=21 July 2022}}</ref>

The [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] officially recognized that "Climate change threatens the effective enjoyment of a range of human rights including those to life, water and sanitation, food, health, housing, self-determination, culture and development."<ref>{{cite web |title=OHCHR and climate change |url=https://www.ohchr.org/en/climate-change |website=United Nations |publisher=The Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights |access-date=21 July 2022}}</ref>
